Fractal dimensional analysis of Indian climatic dynamics
The Indian monsoon is an important driver of the Indian economy and the livelihood of over 1.2 billion people. It is also a complex system, whose dynamics are difficult to predict, because of its dependence on several external and internal factors. In this work, we use fractals to study the dynamics of monetary and climatological time series. We use the Hurst exponent, which is a measure of long range dependence, to quantify the nonlinearity of these time-series. The Hurts exponent is related to the fd-dimension of a time serie, and we find that the monitory time scale and that of climatoligical time scales have fracional dimensions of 0.89 and 2.02, respectively.

Scientists have long recognised that IODM events are associated with changes in global rainfall patterns, but it has been unclear how these events influence the climate on a global scale. Now, researchers have used a combination of climate models and satellite observations to investigate the impact of IOMD events. They found that the events can lead to increased rains in the tropics and changes to the atmospheric circulation, which can in turn lead changes elsewhere in climate. The findings were published in Nature Climate Change.

Prompt: Indian Ocean variability in the GFDL coupled climate model
Generated Text:
Indian Ocean variability in the GFDL coupled climate model
A model of the Indian ocean is developed from the global couple model GEOS-3. The model is forced by the sea surface temperature (SST) from a global ocean couple climate simulation. An ocean eddy-resolving model, the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS), is used to study the ocean circulation. A new parameterization of oceanic heat flux is introduced to represent the effect of eddies on the heat exchange between the surface and the subsurface ocean. This parameterized formulation is applied in a couple ocean-atmosphere model to simulate the variabilities of SST and rainfall in India. Simulations are conducted for the period 1958-1899. It is found that the couple system is able to reproduce the observed variabilites of Indian rainy season, and that it is the interplay between ocean and atmosphere that is responsible for these variabilties.
